questions.text: Which among the following does not constitute a part of the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
The Sphincter urethrae is not a component of the superficial perineal pouch. It's a component of the deep perineal pouch.  

Superficial Perineal Pouch 

It's the space between the perineal membrane and the deep membranous layer of superficial fascia. 

Boundaries of Superficial Perineal Pouch 

Inferior:  Membranous layer of the superficial fascia.
Superior: Perineal Membrane.
Lateral:  Ischiopubic rami.

Contents of Superficial Perineal Pouch 
 
  • Root(Crura) of penis/clitoris and muscles associated (Ischicavernous)
  • Bulb of penis/vestibule and muscles associated (Bulbospongiosus)
  • Corpus cavernosum and spongiosum
  • Ducts of bulbourethral(male)/greater vestibular glands(female)
  • Superficial Transverse perineal muscle
  • Branches of the internal pudendal artery (posterior scrotal/labial artery and vein
  • Artery to bulb (males)/vestibule (females)
  • Branches of the pudendal nerve(posterior scrotal/labial nerve)



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1256,1257

questions.solution:
• The left phrenic nerve does not pass through the esophageal hiatus in the diaphragm.

         vaGus

choices.text: Sympathetic fibres from the fronto-orbital branch of V nerve
Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres from cervical sympathetic chain

questions.text: Which of the following supplies the dilator pupillae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres from cervical sympathetic chain
 
  • The dilator pupillae muscle is responsible for dilating the pupil of the eye and is part of the iris.
  • The control of the pupil size involves both sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers.
  • Post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus travel in the oculomotor (III) cranial nerve and innervate the sphincter pupillae muscle, which causes pupillary constriction (miosis).
  • Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers from the cervical sympathetic chain travel through the sympathetic pathway and innervate the dilator pupillae muscle, causing pupillary dilation (mydriasis).

  


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 781

choices.text: At the end of 2nd month of pregnancy
At the beginning of 5th month of pregnancy
At the end of 3rd month of pregnancy
At the end of 4th month of pregnancy

questions.text: Which month of pregnancy shows the onset of the first ossification center?
questions.solution:
An ossification center is a site where the ossification of the cartilage begins.

The first center of ossification appears at around 7-8 weeks in utero i.e. at the end of 2nd month of pregnancy and between 9-12 weeks POG (period of gestation), a primary ossification center appears in most bones.

Important Ossification centers appearing before birth 

Lower Limb
 

7 weeks in utero Tibial Shaft
8 weeks in utero Femoral/Fibular Shaft
9 weeks in utero Metarsals


Pelvis
 

8 weeks in utero Ilium
18 weeks in utero Ischium
20 weeks in utero Pubis

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.621

choices.text: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it
Glucose concentration in the capillaries is the same as that in glomerular filtrate
Constriction of afferent arteriole decrease the blood flow to the glomerulas
Hematocrit of the fluid leaving the capillaries is more than that of the fluid entering it

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding glomerular capillaries is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it

Option 1 : the oncotic pressure of fluid leaving the capillaries is more than that of fluid entering as last amino acids and proteins are not filtered through that glomerular membrane but plasma is freely filtered. Thus the oncotic pressure increases
Option 2 : the glucose concentration in the capillaries is same as that in the glomerular filtrate as glucose is freely filtered through the membrane via the fenestrated endothelium and the negatively charged membrane.
Option 3 : Constriction of Afferent arteriole will lead to reduced blood flow in the glomerular capillaries leading to decreased GFR. Constriction of efferent arteriole on the other hand leads to increased contact time of blood with the bowman’s capsule and thus increased GFR
Option 4 : hematocrit is the ratio of volume of RBCs to the volume of blood. the hematocrit of the fluid leaving the glomerular capillaries is generally the same as or slightly higher than that of the fluid entering it. This occurs because the glomerular capillaries primarily filter small molecules, ions, and water, while larger molecules such as red blood cells are not usually filtered. Consequently, the concentration of red blood cells and the hematocrit remain relatively constant throughout the process of filtration in the glomerulus.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 665-669

questions.text: How is the mean arterial pressure calculated?
questions.solution:
Mean arterial pressure is calculated as (SBP + 2DBP)/3. 




Reference- https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15558774/

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of hypothermia?
questions.solution:
One of the deleterious effects of hypothermia is increased peripheral vascular resistance as body tries to conserve the core body temperature causing cutaneous vasoconstriction. Hypothermia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, reversible coagulopathy, increased pulmonary systemic vascular resistance, decreased cardiac output and renal blood flow, renal failure (in severe), cold induced diuresis (in mild cases), dehydration, maladaptive behavior and leftward shift of oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 261,314

questions.text: Who received the Nobel Prize for discovering the structure and amino acid sequence of insulin as well as the  differences in molecular structure between species?
questions.solution:
Frederick Sanger discovered the structure and amino acid sequence of insulin as well as the interspecies differences in molecular structure and got the Nobel Prize for that.

  • Prof. JJ Abel crystallized insulin but did not elucidate its structure.

  • Rutter, Goodman, and Uhlich were involved in other insulin-related research, such as its gene cloning.

  • Frederick Banting and Charles Best were co-discoverers of insulin as a hormone in 1921, but their work was unrelated to the sequence determination.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 26.

questions.text: Which category does the receptors for dopamine, noradrenaline, and adrenaline fall under?
questions.solution:
Cell surface receptors are usually of three types:

1.  Ion channel-linked receptors (Ligand-gated or voltage-gated)
2. Enzyme-linked receptors
3. GPCR (G Protein-coupled receptors)

The receptors for adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine (catecholamines) are G- protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs).
GPCRs span the cell membrane 7 times; hence are also referred to as seven pass (seven helix) or serpentine receptors.(option 3)



Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition Page no: 59

questions.text: Which of the following receptors needs to be activated to prevent excessive tidal volume load?
questions.solution:
Tidal volume excessive load is prevented by activation of slowly adapting pulmonary or bronchial stretch receptors. ). Stretching of the lungs during inspiration initiates impulses in afferent pulmonary vagal fibers, which innervate the pulmonary stretch receptors. These impulses inhibit inspiratory discharge from the DRG.( Dorsal respiratory group).

Other options:- 
J receptors in lungs respond to pulmonary edema and cause tachypnea. Carotid and aortic baroreceptors respond to changes in blood pressure 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 645-657

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of gut flora in humans?
questions.solution:
• Fermentation of mucus is not a primary function of gut flora in human beings
Functions of gut flora
  • Digestion of carbohydrate
  • Repression of pathogenic microbial growth.
  • Prevention of allergy
  • Prevention of inflammatory bowel disease/carcinoma
  • Metabolic function: Produces vitamin K and biotin


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3667473/

choices.text: Clathrin-coated pits contain the receptor on cell membrane
It is taken into the cells by endocytosis
Increased cellular cholesterol down-regulates the synthesis of LDL receptors

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding LDL receptors is not true?
questions.solution:
LDL receptor is present on liver as well as on extrahepatic tissue.
Negatively charged glycoprotein LDL (apo B-100, E) receptors are found on the cell membrane in depressed coated pits that are coated on cytosolic side with a protein called clathrin.
LDL is taken up intact by endocytosis.
The influx of cholesterol inhibits the transcription of the genes encoding HMG-CoA synthase, HMG­ CoA reductase and other enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis, as well as the LDL receptor itself.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 267.

questions.text: Which response regarding isoenzymes is correct?
questions.solution:
Isozymes are enzymes that differ in amino acid sequence but catalyze the same chemical reaction. Isozymes usually have different kinetic parameters (e.g. different KM values), structure, electr-ophoretical properties and are regulated differently. They may differ even in their classification.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 61.

questions.text: Regarding oxygenases, which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution:
Oxygenase (which belongs to oxido-reductase class) causes incorporation of 2 atoms of oxygen (dioxygenase) or 1 atom of O (mono-oxygenase or hydroxylase). They oxidize a substrate by catalyzing the incorporation of oxygen into a substrate.
Monooxygenases, also called hydroxylases or mixed-function oxidases as they catalyze the incorporation of one atom of an oxygen molecule into the substrate, while the other atom is reduced to water.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 114.

choices.text: Net loss of muscle protein due to increased break-down
Leakage from cells due to membrane damage

questions.text: What is the main cause of increased serum levels of alanine after a fast?
questions.solution:
Increased levels of alanine in serum after fasting are primarily due to net loss of muscle protein due to increased breakdown.
Alanine is synthesized and secreted from the skeletal muscle that is used as substrates of gluconeogenesis in the liver.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 282.

questions.text: What is a chymotrypsinogen?
questions.solution:
Chymotrypsinogen or prochymotrypsin is a proprotein, proenzyme or zymogen.It is activated by Chymotrypsin. Chymotrypsin is an endopeptidase, breaking the peptide bond formed by alpha carboxyl group of amino acids.



Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/biochemistry-genetics-and-molecular-biology/zymogen

questions.text: How many different amino acids may possibly be coded by such a system, if  a 4 nucleotides sequence code for an amino acid instead of 3?
questions.solution:
If there would have been two nucleotides in each codon, the chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to the power 2, i.e. 16, and three nucleotide in each codon means there will occur 4 raised to the power 3 , i.e. 64 codons are possible. According to the above calculation, if there occurs 4 nucleotides in a codon, tire chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to power 4, i.e. 256.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Why are there multiple codons for the same amino acid?
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is the redundancy of the genetic code, where more than one triplet codes one amino acid. Degeneracy means the coding of a particular amino acid by more than one codon. Since numerous distinct codons define the same amino acid, the genetic code degenerates. This allows for greater permutations and combinations to code for a particular amino acid.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: Which of the following polypeptides is produced by the translation of the m-RNA poly (A) tail?
questions.solution:
Poly A tail is translated into the polylysine tail as AAA is the codon for lysine amino acid. The poly-A tail makes the RNA molecule more stable and prevents its degradation. Additionally, the poly-A tail allows the mature messenger RNA molecule to be exported from the nucleus and translated into a protein by ribosomes in the cytoplasm.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 412.

questions.text: What is CAP in LAC operon an example of?
questions.solution:
CAP in LAC operon is an example of positive regulator. CAP-cAMP regulator is a positive regulator for Lac operon because its presence is required for gene expression. Operon = structural genes coding for enzymes of metabolic pathway + regulatory genes that determine their transcription.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 423.

choices.text: Genomic DNA from beta cells of pancreas of humans
m-RNA from beta cells of pancreas of humans

questions.text: What is the starting substance for bacterial synthesis of insulin?
questions.solution:
Starting material for production of insulin from bacteria is m-RNA from beta cells of pancreas of humans. Isolation of a specific gene from the human DNA is a laborious process. It is thus easier to start the process by obtaining insulin mRNA from the beta cells of the pancreas where insulin is being produced in abundance.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 417.

questions.text: In a polymerase chain reaction, which of the following is not used?
questions.solution:
Dideoxyribonucleotides are not used in polymerase chain reaction. The key ingredients of a PCR reaction are Taq polymerase, primers, template DNA, and nucleotides (DNA building blocks).

Dideoxyribonucleotides are used in Sanger's sequencing. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: Which of the following moiety(s) fills the 40 nm space between the tropocollagen molecule in collagen, which serves as the site of bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Ca2+

The ends of tropocollagen subunits contain gaps which measure ~ 40 nm.
These gaps serve as the nucleation sites for deposition of calcium in the form of calcium hydroxyapatite.
This turns collagen in cartilage that is softer to hard bone.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 601.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants will you use to send a sample for blood glucose assessment when employed at PHC?
questions.solution:
Potassium oxalate and sodium fluoride are antiglycolytic agents (Sodium Fluoride inhibits the Enolase enzyme in Glycolysis); hence, it's used for blood collection for blood glucose estimation.

       

 

Reference-Dacie and Lewis Practical Haematology 11th Edition Page no 4, 5

questions.text: Which substance most effectively inhibits the carnitine palmitate acyl transferase on the outer mitochondrial membrane in a well-fed state?
questions.solution:
In a well fed state, the carnitine palmitate acyl transferase on the outer mitochondrial membrane is most potently inhibited by malonyl CoA. The carnitine shuttle represents a mechanism by which long-chain fatty acids, which are impermeable to the mitochondrial membranes, are transported into the mitochondrial matrix for the purpose β-oxidation and energy production.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 223.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have a role in eukaryotes' ability to synthesise proteins?
questions.solution:
RNA polymerase enzyme is involved in the transcription process(DNA-> RNA) - not in translation.
Ribosomes, Peptidyl transferase, and aminoacyl t -RNA synthetase - all are involved in the process of Translation(synthesis of proteins from RNA). 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 358.

choices.text: Decreased essential fatty acids in the liver

questions.text: What determines the rate of gluconeogenesis during extended starvation?
questions.solution:
During prolonged starvation, the rate of gluconeogenesis depends upon increased alanine levels in liver. Alanine is synthesized and secreted from the skeletal muscle that is used as substrates of gluconeogenesis in the liver. Alanine is exported to the liver where it is transaminated to pyruvate, which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: All of the following, with the exception of ______________ can be used to detect chromosomal mutations.
questions.solution:
Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) is a technique used to detect mutations or variations in DNA sequences. It separates double-stranded DNA molecules based on their melting behavior, which is dependent on their nucleotide sequence. This technique is particularly useful in detecting point mutations, deletions, and insertions in PCR-amplified DNA fragments.
On the other hand, Single strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP), Dideoxynucleotide trial sequencing, and Agarose gel electrophoresis are also methods used to detect chromosomal mutations.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: Mental retardation is usually linked to subtelomeric gene rearrangements. Except for one, all of the following can be used to diagnose them, namely:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Matrix assisted laser desorption and ionization (MALDI)

Matrix assisted laser deposition and ionization is used for rapid identification of proteins as well as post translational modification.
Rest of the given options are used to detect sub telomeric gene rearrangements.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 31.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely related to an abnormal HAM test?
questions.solution:
Abnormal HAM test is most likely associated with defective GPI anchor protein, used as screening of test for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. Patient red blood cells (RBCs) are placed in mild acid; a positive result (increased RBC fragility) indicates PNH.
PNH is characterized by the typical clinical triad of hemolytic anemia, bone marrow failure, and propensity to thromboembolism.

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 648

questions.text: In idiopathic steroid resistance nephrotic syndrome (SRNS), what is the most frequent gene deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) NPHS-2
 
  • The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is NPHS-2 (which codes for podocin) Mutations in NPHS2 result in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Affected children usually show pathologic features of FSGS.
  • A distinctive pattern of autosomal recessive FSGS results from mutations in the NPHS2 gene, which maps to chromosome 1q25–q31 and encodes the protein product podocin. Podocin has also been localized to the slit diaphragm. Mutations in NPHS2 result in a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset.
  • Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 underlie some cases of autosomal dominant FSGS, which can be insidious in onset but has a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 916.

questions.text:
A individual with reflux nephropathy, as determined by radiology, develops proteinuria of the nephritic range. Which of the following would most likely
describe the patient's histology findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
 
  • Most likely histologic findings in the patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy and nephritic range proteinuria is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
  • The cause of nephrotic syndrome is characterized by the presence of focal (only some glomeruli are affected) and segmental (only a part of the glomerulus is affected) sclerosis of the glomeruli.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: What is the preferred anticoagulant for coagulation tests?
questions.solution:
Trisodium citrate(option 1) is the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation tests. The most commonly used anticoagulant for in vitro coagulation studies is citric acid. It is generally employed in the form of sodium citrate.



 
 

Reference:Dacie and Lewis Practical Haematology 11th Edition Page no 4,5

questions.text: Which of the following outcomes occurs in acute inflammation caused by the retraction of endothelial cell cytoskeleton?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Early transient increase in permeability
 
  • Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in opening of inter-endothelial gaps is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage. It is elicited by histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, and other chemical mediators. It is called the immediate transient response because it occurs rapidly after exposure to the mediator and is usually short-lived (15 to 30 minutes).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman has been receiving hemodialysis for the past 8 years and has renal failure. She experienced Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.
Which of the following amyloid types will be linked to it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Beta-2 microglobulin
 
  • Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure develop amyloidosis as a result of deposition of beta-microglobulin deposition.
  • Amyloidosis is a pathological proteinaceous substance deposited between cells in various tissues and organs of the body.
  • Common Biopsy sites in Amyloidosis: Subcutaneous abdominal at aspirate, Rectum, Skin.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 264.

choices.text: Immediately refrigerate to preserve coagulant factor function

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding prothrombin time measurement?
questions.solution:
Option (1) is the correct statement - Prothrombin time should be measured within 2 hours.

Option (2) -The sample should be kept at room temperature; not refrigerated.
Option (3)- Platelet-poor plasma is used for the examination.
Option (4) - Activation is done with thromboplastin (derived from rabbit brain or lung).
Activation with kaolin is done for aPTT, not for PT.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544269/

questions.text:
Previously, two blood transfusions were necessary for a 6-year-old child who is pallorous now. Fever and petechial haemorrhages have also appeared in him.
His Hb is 9 gm/dL, platelet count is 20,000/mm3 and 60,000/mm3, respectively.
The results of flow cytometry show that CD-10 +ve, CD-19 +ve, CD-33 - ve, CD-117 +ve, MPO +ve and CD-3 -ve.
The diagnosis that is most likely is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Mixed phenotypic acute leukemia
 
  • The most likely diagnosis is mixed phenotypic acute leukemia.
  • Mixed-phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) is a rare but difficult-to-treat hematologic malignancy with immunophenotypic co-expression of at least two cell lineages, or with only rare cases involving all three lineages, e.g. myeloid with B- or T-lymphoid or all three of myeloid, B- and T-lymphoid altogether
  • In the given case scenario -CD10 and CD19 are B-lymphoid markers whereas CD117 and myeloperoxidase are myeloid lineage markers and hence, the child likely has MPAL (Mixed Phenotypic Acute leukemia) 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text: A female patient, aged 22, describes having chronic joint discomfort and joint in the past. She is now noticing multiple ecchymotic patches. Most likely, she has what?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Acquired factor VIII inhibitors
 
  • The clinical presentation in a young female with recurrent joint pains with ecchymotic hemorrhage is suggestive of an autoimmune disease.
  • Options '1', '2', and '3' would present with mucosal bleeding episodes (epistaxis/petechia/gum bleeds and not ecchymosis) and they would also be present since birth.
  • A female patient is unlike to have hemophilia, as it is an X-linked disorder. However, she can have autoantibodies against factor VIII - which then can cause ecchymotic patches.
  • Joint pain given in the clinical stem can also be due to hemarthrosis which is common with factor VIII deficiency. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Which statement regarding octreotide is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Used in secretory diarrhea

Octreotide is used in secretory diarrhea. Octreotide is an octapeptide analog of somatostatin, effective in inhibiting the severe secretory diarrhea brought about by hormone-secreting tumors of the pancreas and the GI tract. It is preferentially administered subcutaneously.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 928.

questions.text: Which of the following does not prevent T4 to T3 conversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methimazole
 
  • Methimazole and carbimazole do not block the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Methimazole and carbimazole interfere with the oxidation of the iodide ion and iodotyrosyl groups. Eventually, thyroglobulin gets depleted and circulating thyroid hormone levels decrease.
  • All other drugs mentioned prevent conversion of T4 to T3. Thus Propranolol and Propylthiouracil are used in management of Thyroid storm.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 269.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not correctly matched with their metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Digoxin: p-glycoprotein
 
  • P-glycoprotein is not involved in the metabolism of digoxin it is involved in Efflux of the drug. Metabolism and Elimination of drug, and Toxicity parameter depends on both but as question on Metabolism specifically answer have to be 1.
  • Digoxin has small amount of Hepatic metabolism via Glucuronide and Hydrolysis in liver and then rest mostly in large intestine by bacteria.
  • The cytochrome P450 (CYP) isoform CYP3A4 serves as the major pathway for metabolism of lovastatin, simvastatin and atorvastatin.
  • Carvedilol is extensively metabolized by oxidation by CYP1D6 and CYP2C9.
  • Verapamil is metabolized CYP3A4.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 141.

choices.text: Highly specific, competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, non-competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following properties best describes brinzolamide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
 
  • Brinzolamide is a highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It is administered topically but systemic absorption is significant. Primarily excreted unchanged in urine.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibition reduces aqueous production and decreases intraocular pressure. Its indication is glaucoma.
  • Side effects include blurring of vision, itching, headache and runny nose.

Online Reference:
Iester M. Brinzolamide ophthalmic suspension: a review of its pharmacology and use in the treatment of open angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension. Clin Ophthalmol. 2008 Sep;2(3):517-23. doi: 10.2147/opth.s3182. PMID: 19668749; PMCID: PMC2694021.

choices.text: Urinary Sodium and potassium increases, Urinary calcium increases
Urinary Sodium and potassium increased, Urinary calcium decreases
Urinary Sodium and calcium increases, Urinary potassium decreases
Urinary Potassium and calcium increases, Urinary sodium decreases

questions.text: Thiazides are prescribed to a 35-year-old male to treat his primary hypertension. What would be his urinary sodium, potassium, and calcium levels after taking the medication?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics, commonly used to treat hypertension, have specific effects on urinary sodium, potassium, and calcium levels due to their mechanism of action on the nephron.

Mechanism of action:

  1. Sodium: Thiazides inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+Cl-)symporter in the DCT (distal convoluted tubule), leading to increased excretion of sodium (natriuresis).
  2. Potassium: As sodium excretion increases, more sodium is delivered to the collecting duct. This stimulates RAAS- and aldosterone enhances sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium secretion, leading to increased potassium excretion and urinary potassium (kaliuresis).
  3. Calcium: Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion by enhancing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.
Hence, expected urinary changes
 
  • Urinary Sodium: Increased (Natriuresis)
  • Potassium: Increased(Kaliuresis)
  • Calcium: Decreased
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 628, 629.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below can be applied as a transcranial patch to treat Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rotigotine
 
  • Rotigotine can be used as a transcranial patch for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease.
  • It is a dopamine agonist that works on the nervous system to help treat the symptoms of Parkinson disease.
  • Rotigotine is also used to treat a condition called Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS).
  • Rotigotine should not be stopped abruptly because sudden withdrawal of Dopaminergic agonists has been associated with a syndrome resembling neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 418.

questions.text: What is bremelanotide used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Low sexual desire
 
  • Bremelanotide injection (given Sc) is used to treat hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women who previously had no problems with sexual desire.
  • Bremelanotide acts as a melanocortin receptor agonist, specifically targeting the melanocortin-4 receptor (MC4R) in the brain. It is believed to increase sexual desire and arousal by stimulating the presynaptic MC4R (causing release of dopamine), which plays a role in regulating sexual function

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: What results in lid retraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Apraclonidine
 
  • Apraclonidine causes lid retraction. Apraclonidine 1% eye drops are used to prevent or reduce increased pressure in the eye during and after certain types of laser eye surgery.
  • Apraclonidine is in a class of medications called alpha-2-adrenergic agonists. It lowers the pressure in the eye by decreasing the amount of fluid produced within the eye.

* Other options:-
Option 2 Brominidine- side effects include transient myopia, periorbital dermatitis.
Option 3 and 4 Bimatoprost and Travoprost are prostaglandin analogues, side effects includes trichomegaly, cystoid macular edema and pigmentation of iris. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text:
An infection at the location of a wound occurred in a patient who underwent abdominal surgery. MRSA was identified by culture of a wound swab.
Except for__________ all of the other antibiotics may be used for this treatment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cefaclor

Cefaclor is a second generation cephalosporin. Only fifth generation cephalosporins like ceftaroline and ceftobiprole are effective against MRSA.

*Drugs used for treatment of MRSA infection-
•Vancomycin (DOC)

questions.text: In which of the following chloroquine-related eye disease risks is not considered to be high?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Duration of use > 2 years
 
  • Duration of use > 5 years is considered a high-risk factor for development of CQ -Related eye disease.
  • The pathogenesis of hydroxychloroquine-induced retinal toxicity is poorly understood. As chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are known inhibitors of autophagy, these drugs alkalinize lysosomes, thereby, inhibiting lysosomal enzymes and arresting autophagy—although these mechanisms may be dose-dependent.
  • There is an insignificant risk in the first 5 years of therapy, although, in the highest dose group (>5 mg/kg/day), the risks at 10, 15, and 20 years were approximately 10%, 20%, and 40%, respectively.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 879.
Online Reference: Yusuf IH, Charbel Issa P, Ahn SJ. Hydroxychloroquine-induced Retinal Toxicity. Front Pharmacol. 2023 May 30;14:1196783. doi: 10.3389/fphar.2023.1196783. PMID: 37324471; PMCID: PMC10267834.

questions.text: What does the medication efavirenz inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) HIV reverse transcriptase
 
  • Efavirenz is in a class of medications called non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs).
  • NNRTIs primarily block HIV-1 replication by preventing reverse transcriptase from completing reverse transcription of the viral single-stranded RNA genome into DNA.
  • They are well absorbed from GIT; bioavailability increased with a high fat meal. It is metabolized by oxidation by CYP2D6 and CYP3A4.
NNRTI memorizing trick: - END RTI
Efavirenz
Nevirapine
Delavirdine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 863.

questions.text: What is the latest oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for preventing acute stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dabigatran
  • The most recent oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for acute stroke prevention is Dabigatran.
  • Dabigatran is used to treat deep vein thrombosis (DVT; a blood clot, usually in the leg) and pulmonary embolism (PE; a blood clot in the lung). Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) are small molecules that inhibit thrombin directly, with no need for a cofactor.
  • DTI action results in specific inhibition of free and fibrin-bound thrombin, thereby preventing:
                            -Fibrin formation
                         -Thrombin-mediated activation of FV, FVIII, FXI, and FXIII.
                      -Thrombin induced platelet aggregation.

Option 1 Ximelagatran has been investigated in several large randomized controlled studies for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism occurring after major orthopedic surgery, therapy in vein thrombosis, stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, and acute coronary syndromes. It is a Prodrug of melagatran.
Option 2 Idraparinux is a heparinoid Penta saccharide, antithrombin III-dependent Factor Xa inhibitor
Option 4 warfarin works as an anticoagulant by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) in the liver.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 672.

choices.text: It is time consuming and extremely costly
It is based on trial and error
Structure of biological target is obtained via Xray crystallography
Not a part of rational drug designing

questions.text: What is true about structural drug designing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) The structure of the biological target is obtained via Xray crystallography
 
  • Rational design of drugs refers to the ability to predict the appropriate molecular structure of a drug on the basis of information about its biological receptor.
  • Structure-based drug design is becoming an essential tool for faster and more cost-efficient lead discovery relative to the traditional method.
  • The 3D structures of all therapeutically important proteins are determined experimentally by integrative structure biology techniques such as NMR, X-ray crystallography, or cryo-electron microscopy.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the pharmacological basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 4.

questions.text: Symptoms of a fever, chest pain, and dry cough in an older male were present. Gram negative organism was discovered when his sputum was cultivated on charcoal yeast medium. Which organism is more likely?
questions.solution:
Presence of fever with respiratory symptoms and growth on BCYE( Buffered charcoal yeast extract) media confirms the diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia. Culture of the organism is the single most definitive diagnostic test for Legionella. Growth of Legionella pneumophila on buffered charcoal-yeast extract (BCYE) medium is dependent on l-cysteine, which is added in excess over what is required for nutrition.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 408.

Plasmid mediated resistance is a type of horizontal transmission, not the vertical.

B. fragilis is not uniformly sensitive to metronidazole

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with reference to Bacteroides fragilis?

Bacteroides fragilis group comprises the most important anaerobic pathogens in human infections. These pathogens are often associated with polymicrobial infections such as intra-abdominal, obstetric-gynecologic, diabetic foot, and skin and skin structure infections.

questions.text: A young male presents to OPD with urethral discharge. On urine examination, pus cells were found but no organisms. Which of the following media would be the best culture for the organism?
questions.solution:
Urine examination in a patient of urethral discharge demonstrating only pus cells but no gram-negative diplococcic suggest "non-gonococcal urethritis". The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis. Chlamydia trachomatis is cultured on McCoy cells, HeLa cells or Hep-2 cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 426.

questions.text: What does the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involve after the binding of complement and antibodies to the surface of encapsulated bacteria?
questions.solution:
After binding of complement and antibody on the surface of encapsulated bacteria, the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involves C3b and Fc. One of the most efficient ways of enhancing the phagocytosis of particles is coating the particles with IgG antibodies specific for the particles, which are then recognized by the high-affinity Fc receptor of phagocytes.
Components of the complement system, like fragments of the complement protein C3, are also potent opsonins.(C3b)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 177.

questions.text: Having pustular lesions on the lower legs, a 5-year-old from a remote location presented to the OPD. Beta Hemolytic colonies (clear and complete hemolysis) of Gram-positive cocci were visible on the blood agar in the lesion's culture. Which of the following responses could help tentatively confirm the diagnosis of group A streptococcal pyoderma?
questions.solution:
The correct option is option (2) - Bacitracin sensitivity.

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is one of the common causative agents of pyoderma, an acute superficial skin infection that causes pustules and vesicles on the skin. Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic feature of GAS, and it can be used to differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. GAS is susceptible to bacitracin, while other beta-hemolytic streptococci, such as Group B streptococci, are resistant to bacitracin.

Optochin sensitivity is a test that helps to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and other alpha-hemolytic streptococci, including viridans streptococci.

Catalase positivity is a characteristic feature of staphylococci, a group of Gram-positive cocci that are catalase positive, while streptococci are catalase-negative.

Bile solubility is a test that helps to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. S. pneumoniae is bile-soluble, while other alpha-hemolytic streptococci are bile-insoluble.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 211.

questions.text: An ICU patient has been connected to a central venous line for the past week. He is on Amikacin and Ceftazidime. After taking antibiotics for 7 days, he experiences a fever spike and learns that gram-positive, chain-forming, catalase-negative cocci are present in his blood culture. After that, Vancomycin was started, but the culture continued to show the same infection. who are the infectious organisms?
questions.solution:
The common source of nosocomial infection is Enterococcus faecalis, a gram-positive chain-forming, catalase-negative cocci. Unlike other streptococci, enterococci species exhibit penicillin resistance, and they are inherently resistant to all cephalosporins. A high level of resistance to aminoglycosides is also present in enterococci. Vancomycin resistance is a widespread problem.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 220.

questions.text: Which is the very first chemical barrier that microorganisms encounter for a commonly exposed body surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acidic pH
 
  • First chemical barrier encountered by microorganism for common exposed surfaces of the body is acidic pH.
  • All surfaces of the body, which come in contact with the external environment, are equipped with mechanical and chemical barriers to prevent penetration by microorganisms.
  • Secretions of sebaceous glands contain both saturated and unsaturated fatty acids that kill bacteria and fungi.
  • The sebaceous secretions also have a low pH that inhibits bacterial growth.
Online Reference: Janeway CA Jr, Travers P, Walport M, et al. Immunobiology: The Immune System in Health and Disease. 5th edition. New York: Garland Science; 2001. The front line of host defense. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK27105/

questions.text: Which of the following species' spores are used in an autoclave as a control?
questions.solution:
• Spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as a control in the autoclave.
  • Sterilization control of autoclave: For determining the efficacy of moist heat sterilization, spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as test organism. This is a thermophilic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 55-60 degrees and its spores require an exposure of 12 minutes at 121 degrees to be killed.
  • The effectiveness of sterilisation by hot air oven can be monitored by using biological indicators like spores of nontoxigenic strains of Clostridium tetani or Bacillus subtilis subspecies niger.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 32.

questions.text: What is the maximum prison sentence under Section 304A of the IPC for a case of proven medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Under section 304A of IPC, for a proved case of medical negligence, the maximum punishment of imprisonment is up to 2 years.
Professional or medical negligence  is an act of omission or commission, i.e. not-doing something which a reasonable person would do or doing something, which a reasonable person would not do.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 49.

questions.text: Which provision of the IPC provides for the punishment of hostile witnesses who knowingly give false testimony while taking an oath in court?
questions.solution:
A person is liable for punishment for perjury, which is defined under section 193 of IPC. Section 191 IPC defines perjury and section 193 IPC describes the punishment.
Perjury is defined as the offence of willfully telling an untruth or making a misrepresentation under oath.

questions.text: Which organ is best or most favoured for DNA extraction during autopsy:?
questions.solution:
The organ most favored for DNA extraction during an autopsy is the 1. Liver.

The liver is often chosen because it is generally larger and contains a higher quantity of DNA compared to other organs, making it a reliable source for genetic analysis.

 
  • In autopsy, deep muscle tissue samples are most suitable as they are most resistant to decomposition.
  • The next choice is cardiac muscle. Other autopsy samples for DNA are teeth (preferably molar teeth), hair with roots, blood.

Reference: Atmadja DS, Tatsuno Y, Ueno Y, Nishimura A. The effect of extraction methods. The kind of organ samples and the examination delay on the DNA yields and typing. Kobe J Med Sci. 1995 Dec;41(6):197-211. PMID: 8869006.

questions.text: Which type of laceration exhibits flaying?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Avulsion
 
  • Flaying is seen in avulsion.
  • An avulsion is a forcible tearing off of skin or another part of the body, such as an ear or a finger. Any time layers of skin have been torn off to expose muscles, tendons and tissue, it is called an avulsion.
  • Shearing laceration due to horizontal impact (or shearing and grinding force) at an acute angle resulting in avulsion or degloving of skin. e.g. lorry wheel causing degloving of skin known as flaying.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 191.

questions.text: When performing palatoprints to identify a person, from which part of the hard palate are the prints taken from?
questions.solution:

Palatoprints are used for identification of the person, is performed by taking prints from anterior part of the hard palate.
Palatal rugoscopy is the study of palatal rugae, and their uniqueness to individuals can provide a reliable source of identification. Palatal rugae are irregular, asymmetric ridges of mucous membrane.

questions.text: Most common age group for CLL is :

Correct option is 4: Above 50 years

  • Associated with Warm Antibody mediated Autoimmune hemolytic anemia 
  • Peripheral smear: small round blue lymphocytes, smudge cells

choices.text: Not responsible for his act under section 84, IPC

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic man, 45, who allegedly assaulted his neighbour in the past, is brought to the emergency room. He has irrelevant talk, according to an evaluation. For the previous four days, he had abstained from drinking. His condition is deemed to be delirium tremens. The person is in this circumstance:
questions.solution:
Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that involves sudden and severe mental or nervous system changes. It is considered as unsoundness of mind and not  intoxication.
Thus if delirium tremens can be proved, the person cannot be held responsible for his offence under section 84 of the IPC.
Section 84 IPC states that: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person, who at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to the law.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 493.

questions.text: Which epidemiology study provides the most reliable results when comparing two drugs in clinical trials?

questions.text: Which of the following does not affect the equilibrium in Hardy-Weinberg's law?
questions.solution:
Random mating does not affect the equilibrium in Hardy-Weinberg's law.
  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is a principle stating that the genetic variation in a population will remain constant from one generation to the next in the absence of disturbing factors.
 
  • Five conditions are required in order for a population to remain at Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium—
• A large breeding population
• Random mating
• No change in allelic frequency due to mutation
• No immigration or emigration
• No natural selection
 

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardy%E2%80%93Weinberg_principle

choices.text: EBM depends on clinical model and decisions analysis to base its recommendations
EBM objectively evaluates the quality of clinical research by critical assessment techniques reported by researchers in publications

The strongest argument for the therapeutic intervention is systemic review or meta-analysis of triple blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trials with allocation concealment and complete follow-up involving a homogenous population of patients or medical disorders
The weakest argument is the opinion of experts or medical boards

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Evidence Based Medicine (EBM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: EBM depends on clinical model and decisions analysis to base its recommendations

Evidence-based medicine depends on the consolidation of multiple studies, clinical trials conducted, case reports and experience of the researchers. Thus clinical model and decision analysis based recommendations is a wrong statement.
The principle of evidence-based medicine (EBM) is that actual evidence, rather than opinion, must be the primary scientific basis for making clinical decisions; different types of evidence are judged to be of different value.

Systematic reviews and Meta-analysis are components of EBM.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 61.

choices.text: Prior probability of SLE; sensitivity and specificity of each test

questions.text: Clinically identifying the patient as having SLE, you have prescribed six tests. Out of which two tests are negative and four tests are positive. What do you need to know in order to calculate the probability of SLE at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Prior probability of SLE; sensitivity and specificity of each test

In the given question, 6 tests have been performed on a person who has been clinically diagnosed as having SLE.

2 tests gave negative results and 4 tests gave positive results.
In the question, the probability of SLE at the present time has been asked, that is the YIELD that has been asked.

YIELD – It is defined as the amount of previously unrecognised disease that is getting diagnosed as a result of screening tests.
      It depends on the following factors :-
  • Sensitivity of the test
  • Specificity of the test
  • Prevalence of the disease/ probability of having the disease
  • Participation of individuals in the detection program.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 70, 71.

questions.text: In order to compare the mortality rates between two nations, direct standardisation is used because of the differences__________ in this is done.
questions.solution:
Direct standardization is used to compare the mortality rates between two countries.
  • This is done because of the difference in age distributions.
  • In the direct standardization method, the rate that we would expect to find in the populations under study if they all had the same composition according to the variable which effect we wish to adjust or control (such as age, socioeconomic group, or other characteristics) is calculated.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Hb was calculated in a blood sample using a novel method. The test was run ten times. The reports were: 9.5, 9.2, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5, and 12.1. Standard tests determined that the accurate value of Hb was 10.2. The new method includes the following features:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Low validity and low reliability

RELIABILITY –
  • It signifies to the fact that a test if repeated on the same individual or material under same conditions it must give consistent results each time.
  • Also known as REPEATABILITY, REPRODUCIBILITY, PRECISION

VALIDITY –
  • It refers to what extent the test accurately measures what it is intended to measure
  • Also known as ACCURACY

In the given question ,
  • The test is repeated again and again and it’s giving different result each time. Therefore, the reliability is low
  • The test when repeated again and again the values are all haphazard and mostly not close to the actual value of 10.2 given by the standard test. Therefore, the validity or accuracy is low.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 68, 69.

questions.text: An association between the sale of anti-asthmatic drugs and a rise in mortality from anti-asthmatic side effects was discovered in a UK study. This kind of research is an illustration of:
questions.solution:
• In a study in UK, an association was found between sale of anti-asthmatic drug and an increase in deaths due to side effects of anti-asthmatic. This type of study is an example of ecological study.

questions.text: Which is the best method to compare new tests to gold standard test?
questions.solution:
Best method to compare new test and gold standard test is Bland and Altman analysis.
  • Bland-Altman analysis is a statistical method, which allows the clinician to compare two different measurement techniques.
  • Bland-Altman graph plots the difference between two techniques against their averages.
  • Typically used to compare measurement techniques against a reference value, especially when the reference value may not have a true gold standard.
Online Reference: Bland, J. M., & Altman, D. G. (1986). Statistical methods for assessing agreement between two methods of clinical measurement. The Lancet, 1(8476), 307-310. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(86)90837-8.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in preleukemic conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria
 
  • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a pre-leukemic condition.
  • Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) is a benign self-limiting autoimmune hemolytic anemia. PCH does not undergo leukemic transformation and is hence not considered a pre-leukemic condition.
  • Recovery is the rule in Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria.
  • PNH may terminate in Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Other options mentioned are also believed to be preleukaemic conditions.
