questions.text: A 72-year-old guy who has healthy kidney function shows up with recent-onset focal seizures. Which of the following medications is ideal for treating the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Oxcarbazepine
 
  • Among the options provided, oxcarbazepine is the best drug to manage this old patient with normal renal functions and new onset focal seizures.
  • Partial seizure will now be addressed as focal seizure.
  • Drugs to be used for its management are in order of preference Lamotrigine > Oxcarbazepine-Carbamazepine > Phenytoin > Levetiracetam. The change in deciding the best drug is based on side effects and efficacy profile.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

choices.text: Number of senile plaques correlates with age
Number of neurofibrillary tangles is associated with the severity of dementia
Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

Extracellular inclusions cannot be observed in the absence of intracellular inclusions because neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular accumulations that may manifest extracellularly following neuronal death. Other statements given are true.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Limb girdle muscle dystrophies do not include which of the following groups of disorders?
questions.solution:
Calpainopathies, Sarcoglycanopathies, and dysferlinopathies are a few instances of Limb Girdle Dystrophies caused by malfunctioning gene/locus.
 
  • The Limb girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) typically manifest with progressive weakness of pelvic and shoulder girdle musculature.
  • Respiratory insufficiency from weakness of diaphragm and cardiomyopathy may occur.
  • However unlike Duchenne dystrophies (Dystrophin) intellectual/unction remains intact.
  • Muscular dystrophies of the Duchenne and Becker types are related with dystrophin gene, and are not limb girdle dystrophies.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3521, 3524.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
• Aphasia, Apraxia, Acalculia and Agnosia may all be seen in Alzheimer's Dementia.
  • Agnosia in Alzheimer's disease usually presents late in the disease and is not included in the ICD-10 Diagnostic criteria for dementia in
  • Alzheimer's disease with early onset and hence may be selected as the single as the single best answer by exclusion.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3370.

choices.text: Immediately taper off valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate and serial drug monitoring in blood

questions.text: There is a history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in a 29-year-old primigravida who is four months pregnant. She has been taking sodium valproate on a consistent basis, but she has just come in to ask for advice on changing her antiepileptic medication. Which advice do you have for her?
questions.solution:
• Continue valproate with serial drug monitoring in the blood of the 4-month old patient having history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.
  • Most women with epilepsy who become pregnant will have an uncomplicated gestation and deliver a normal baby.
  • Changes in seizure frequency are attributed to endocrine effects on the CNS, variations in antiepileptic drug pharmacokinetics (such as acceleration of hepatic drug metabolism or effects on plasma protein binding), and changes in medication compliance.
  • Because the potential harm of uncontrolled convulsive seizures on the mother and fetus is considered greater than the teratogenic effects of antiseizure drugs, it is currently recommended that pregnant women be maintained on effective drug therapy.
  • Patients should also take folate (1–4 mg/d), because the antifolate effects of anticonvulsants are thought to play a role in the development of neural tube defects.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3320, 3323.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below is used to treat multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Interferon beta is used in multiple sclerosis. Interferon-beta should be considered in patients with Relapsing/Remitting MS (RRMS) and Secondary Progressive MS (SPMS) with superimposed relapses.
  • Interferon-beta reduces the attack rate in MS patients and also improves disease severity measures and disease burden.

 
  • Efficacy in MS probably results from immunomodulatory properties including: (1) downregulating expression of MHC molecules on antigen-presenting cells, (2) reducing proinflammatory and increasing regulatory cytokine levels, (3) inhibiting T-cell proliferation, and (4) limiting the trafficking of inflammatory cells in the CNS.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3472.

questions.text: Which of the following is not approved for the treatment of Relapsing Remitting (RRMS) type of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Mycophenolate mofetil is lymphocyte specific oral immunosuppressant that is presently being studied for its role in multiple sclerosis.
  • Presently mycophenolate is not U.S. FDA approved for use in multiple sclerosis.
  • Hence this drug cannot be recommended for the treatment of multiple sclerosis at present.
 
  • Glatiramer acetate reduces the attack rate (whether measured clinically or by MRI) in RRMS.
  • IFN-β should be considered in patients with either relapsing forms of MS (either RRMS or SPMS with superimposed relapses).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3471, 3472.

questions.text: The only drug reported to be effective in slowing the progression of multiple sclerosis on the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Natalizumab is the only drug found to be beneficial in halting the progression on Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) in multiple sclerosis.
 
  • Natalizumab, a recombinant, humanized antibody, binds to α4β1-integrin and blocks its interaction with VCAM-1. As a result, leukocyte migration into brain tissue is inhibited, reducing inflammation and preventing the formation of lesions.
 
  • Natalizumab is highly effective in reducing the attack rate and significantly improves all measures of disease severity in MS (both clinical and MRI).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3470, 3471.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs of demyelinating myelopathy is most unlikely to portend an eventual development into multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Oligoclonal bands are variable; but when bands are present, a diagnosis of MS is more likely, thus absence of oligoclonal bands suggests a less likely progression to MS.
  • Progression to MS is more likely with presence of bilateral optic neuritis, poor prognosis and complete cord transection.

Insidious neurologic progression suggestive of MS (PPMS): [Criteria]
1 year of disease progression (retrospectively or prospectively determined)
PLUS
2 out of the 3 following criteria:

• Evidence for dissemination in space in the brain based on ≥1 T2+ lesions in the MS-characteristic periventricular, juxtacortical, or infratentorial regions
• Evidence for dissemination in space in the spinal cord based on ≥2 T2+ lesions in the cord
• Positive CSF (isoelectric focusing evidence of oligoclonal bands and/or elevated IgG index)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3465, 3466.

questions.text: Of the following illnesses, which one only affects neurons?
questions.solution:
• Spinocerebellar ataxia exclusively affects neurons.
  • Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a group of inherited brain disorders. It affects cerebellum, a part of the brain vital to coordination of physical movement, and sometimes spinal cord.
  • This inherited condition worsens over time and causes specific problems with coordination, usually affecting eyes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3423, 3424.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Contralateral dorsal column involvement.

Brown-Séquard syndrome is a spinal cord injury that affects one side of the spinal cord i.e Hemisection of spinal cord, leading to specific features:



Dorsal column involvement is usually on the same side as the lesion, not contralateral. Therefore, that feature is not seen here.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3446, 3447.

choices.text: Low plasma rennin activity that is not stimulated by volume depletion
Hyperaldosteronism, i.e. increased aldosterone secretion which is not suppressed by volume expansion

questions.text: Which of the following does not meet the criteria for primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperaldosteronism is associated with metabolic alkalosis and not metabolic acidosis.

Criteria for Diagnosis of Primary Hyperaldosteronism include:

•Diastolic hypertension without edema.
•Hypersecretion of aldosterone that does not suppress appropriately in response to volume expansion
•Low plasma rennin levels.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2964-2966.

choices.text: Serum sodium can be as low as 125 mEq/L
Urine sodium is usually normal or slightly low
Vaptans are new FDA approved drugs for its treatment
Water loading test can be used for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about SIADH?
questions.solution:
SIADH is typically characterized by high urinary sodium (Increased rate of excretion of sodium). SIADH is associated low serum sodium levels (<135 meq/L). Vaptans are new FDA approved agents for treatment of SIADH. Patients with SIADH excrete <90% of the water load within four hours and do not produce urine osmolality <100 mOsm/kg. Serum and urine osmolalities are measured .This is known as water loading test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text:
At what point is diabetes mellitus diagnosed?
1. Fasting blood glucose is \(\geq\)100 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)140 mg/dL
2. Fasting blood glucose \(\geq\)125 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)199 mg/mL
3. Level of plasma insulin is \(\geq\)6 IU/dL
4. HbA1C level is > 6.5%
questions.solution:
Glycosylated Haemoglobin (HbA1C) values of> 6.5% represents an independent criteria/or diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus in accordance with the criteria set by the American Diabetic Association, 2024.

Criteria for diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus (Any one of the following):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3095.

questions.text: Thomas Addison made the first mention of Addison's illness. There are still several reports about it coming in from throughout the globe. Which of the following causes of Addison's disease is more prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of Addison disease in India is tuberculous adrenalitis.
 
  • The commonest cause of adrenal insufficiency (Addison s disease) in developing countries like India is Tuberculosis, followed by autoimmune disorders.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2970, 2971.

choices.text: Low tidal volume during assisted ventilation prevents acute lung injury
For outcome of goal-oriented management of sepsis patients, monitoring of central venous pressure, hourly urine output and blood pressure is adequate
Intensive blood glucose monitoring and prevention of hyperglycemia improves survival in critically ill patients
The use of drotrecogin-alfa is restricted to severely ill patients with APACHE score > 25

questions.text: All of the following interventions are supported by evidence in terms of the best management of patients with sepsis in the critical care unit, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• The role of tight control of blood glucose concentration in recovery from critical illness has been addressed in numerous controlled trials.
 
  • Meta analysis of these trials have concluded that use of insulin to lower blood glucose levels to 100-120 mg/dL is potentially harmful and does not improve survival rates.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2246, 2247.

choices.text: A parathyroid hormone-related protein is responsible for causing hypercalcemia in cancer patients
The unionised fraction of calcium in the plasma is an important determinant of PTH secretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Circulating ionized calcium acts directly on the parathyroid gland and acts in a negative feedback fashion to regulate the secretion of PTH. Hypercalcemia is  a common metabolic complication of cancer parathyroid hormone related protein produced by tumour cells( Paraneoplastic syndrome).
Magnesium is required to maintain normal parathyroid secretory responses. Impaired PTH release along with diminished target responses to PTH account for the hypocalcaemia that occasionally occurs in magnesium deficiency.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3170-3172.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female arrived with an Hb of 9 g/dL, an MCV of 55, and a RBC count of 4.5 million per mm3. There is no history of blood transfusions. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in question has:
  • low MCV indicating microcytic anemia (excludes Megaloblastic anemia) and
  • has never required blood transfusion (excludes Thalassemia major).

This patient may therefore have either an lron deficiency anemia or Thalassemia minor. Microcytic anemia with a normal RBC count favours a diagnosis of Thalassemia minor over iron deficiency anemia.




In this question, MENTZER INDEX (MCV/RBC count) = 55/ 4.5= 12.2 (<13).  Therefore, it points more towards Thalassemia minor/trait than IDA.

Next step in this patient would be HPLC to confirm the diagnosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 750, 753.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for Kawasaki illness?
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice of Kawasaki disease is Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg).
 
  • Kawasaki disease causes swelling (inflammation) in children in the walls of small to medium-sized blood vessels that carry blood throughout the body. Kawasaki disease commonly leads to inflammation of the coronary arteries.
 
  • High-dose IV γ-globulin (2 g/kg as a single infusion over 10 h) together with aspirin (100 mg/kg/d for 14 days followed by 3–5 mg/kg per day for several weeks) has been shown to be effective in reducing the prevalence of coronary artery abnormalities when administered early in the course of the disease.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2816.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is the most specific for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• Anti-CCP antibodies are the most specific blood test for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is a chronic systemic inflammatory disease characterized by persistent involvement of synovial membrane of multiple joints and variety of systemic manifestations.
  • The presence of serum anti-CCP antibodies has about the same sensitivity as serum RF for the diagnosis of RA. However, its diagnostic specificity approaches 95%, so a positive test for anti-CCP antibodies in the setting of an early inflammatory arthritis is useful for distinguishing RA from other forms of arthritis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2759.

questions.text: A preoperative coagulation test was performed on a 25-year-old woman with a history of abortion. Her lab results are as follows: PT = 15/14(Control), aPTT = 45/35(control), platelet count = 2.5 lac/mm3. What ailment does she probably have?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Anti-phospholipid syndrome
 
  • The patient in the question has a prolonged aPTT and a normal PT, which is consistent with a lupus anticoagulant. The patient also has a history of abortion, which is a risk factor for APS.
  • Anti-phospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where the body produces antibodies against phospholipids, leading to a paradoxical increase in blood clotting, despite the name.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2750.

choices.text: Aortic valve balloon dilation to prevent further worsening

questions.text: An 11-minute workout is being performed by a 50-year-old man with aortic stenosis as per Bruce's protocol. Fatigue forced the end of the exercise. At rest, his peak systolic gradient across the aortic valve was 60 mmHg. What kind of care is ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Aortic valve replacement

The patient in question has asymptomatic aortic stenosis but develops symptoms on exercise (abnormal/positive exercise test). Also the presence of mean pressure gradient of 60 mm Hg puts this patient into the category of  Severe Aortic Stenosis. Since the patient in question has 'Very Severe AS' and 'Abnormal Stress Testing' he should be considered for surgical intervention in the form of Aortic Valve Replacement (AVR).

Management of Aortic Stenosis is summarised below:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1982, 1983.

choices.text: Sudden unexpected cardiac death with symptoms of ischemia
New regional wall motion abnormally with raised cardiac biomarkers
Three times increase in troponin levels are required for coronary artery bypass grafting
Reinfarction can be diagnosed if increased troponin levels by 5-7% in serial samples

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding Myocardial Infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Three times increase in troponin levels are required for coronary artery bypass grafting.
 
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a surgical procedure that is used to improve blood flow to the heart. It is not typically performed based on troponin levels. 
  • Troponin levels are used to diagnose a heart attack, but they are not used to determine whether or not a patient needs CABG.
Other options:

Option 1: Sudden unexpected cardiac death with symptoms of ischemia is consistent with a myocardial infarction.
Option 2: New regional wall motion abnormality with raised cardiac biomarkers is indicative of myocardial infarction and is one of the criteria for its diagnosis.
Option 4: Reinfarction can be diagnosed if there is an increase in troponin levels by 5-7% in serial samples, suggesting a recurrent myocardial infarction.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2033, 2045, 2057.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presented with fever of one-month duration, ataxia and headache. Dilated ventricles with basal exudates were found during brain imaging. Which among the following is the most likely CSF finding?
questions.solution:
• Presence of significant basal exudates, together with dilated ventricles (hydrocephalus) in a young female with prolonged history of fever and headache suggests a diagnosis of tubercular meningitis.
  • Tubercular meningitis is characterized by lymphocytic pleocytosis (Pleocytosis is the presence of both neutrophils and lymphocytes in CSF), low glucose and high proteins within the CSF.
  • CSF pressure is raised in tubercular meningitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1109.

questions.text: The following lab results were obtained from a 60-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis: Hb 4.5 g/dL, platelet count 2Lac/mm3, TLC 6000/mm3, serum ferritin 300 mg/L, and TIBC 280 ng/L. Which diagnosis is most probable amongst the following given options?
questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease is associated with:
  • decreased serum iron
  • decreased TIBC
  • decreased % saturation
  • normal or increased serum ferritin levels.
 
  • It is characterized by block in delivery of iron from the reticuloendothelial system to the erythroid progenitors due to upregulation of Hepcidin thus inhibiting Ferroportin.
  • On the other hand low serum iron with increased TIBC indicate Iron deficiency anemia.

Diagnosis of Hypoproliferative anemia: 



In this table, Inflammatory cause signifies Anemia of Chronic Disease



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 751, 753.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myelopathy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Jaw jerk is exaggerated in supranuclear lesions that are above the mid pons. It is helpful in localizing the lesion to the brainstem.

Causes of the exaggerated jaw jerk-

•Neurodegenerative diseases
•Pseudobulbar palsy
•Motor neuron disease
•Multiple sclerosis



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3447, 3450.

questions.text: A young male patient is admitted with triglycerides of 140 mg/dl and LDL cholesterol of 600 mg/dl. What would a physical examination likely reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Tendon xanthomas.
 
  • The clinical presentation of elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors.
  • Tendon xanthomas: Yellowish nodules that form on tendons (such as the Achilles tendon), caused by the deposition of cholesterol and other lipids in the tendons.
  • Elevated triglycerides and LDL cholesterol in the patient contribute to tendon xanthomas.
  • The patient's young age is a risk factor for developing tendon xanthomas.

Other options:
 
  • Planar xanthomas: Flat, yellowish patches that form on the skin.
  • Lipemia retinalis: Condition in which the retina (the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye) becomes cloudy due to the accumulation of lipids. 
  • Tuberoeruptive xanthomas: small, yellowish nodules that form on the skin, especially the face and back.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3139, 3141.

questions.text: A woman complains of having abdominal pain. The CECT reveals bilateral papillary necrosis. Which of the following tests should not be performed to find out what caused her papillary necrosis?
questions.solution:
Urine acidification test is mainly done to diagnose RTA (Renal tubular acidosis), NOT the cause of papillary necrosis.

• Though TB is not a major cause but it can cause papillary necrosis, diagnosed by urine RT-PCR.
• Bacterial culture is done for UTI.
• Sickle cell disease can be diagnosed by Sickling test.

Common causes of Renal Papillary Necrosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282, 2348, 2362.

choices.text: Late enhancement on Gadolinium: MRI suggests scar
Akinetic area does not benefit from reperfusion
Low dose dobutamine may be used to detect hibernating myocardium
Rest reinjection thallium is used to detect hibernating myocardium

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
• The contractile function of hibernating myocardium can be completely restored after reperfusion. It is a reversible state of contractile dysfunction observed in the course of chronic ischemia associated with reduction of coronary blood flow without major evidence of irreversible myocardial damage (viable myocardium).
 
  • Ischemia may also manifest as delayed contractility of a segment (Akinetic segment). Ischemia is a dynamic condition, and if sufficient blood flow is restored in time, either through a decrease in metabolic demand (as when a stress test ends) or through reperfusion, contractility of the affected segment can recover rapidly.

 
  • Persistence or increasing severity of the wall motion abnormality after the initial insult implies that the tissue is becoming nonfunctional (i.e., not metabolically active or hibernating) or nonviable (infarcted). Akinetic myocardial segments do not thicken at all, and dyskinetic segments bulge paradoxically outward in systole, thus implying that no functioning myocardium is present

 
  • Any improvement in wall motion abnormality by at least one grade in two or more segments during stress echocardiography with Dobutamine is likely to signify viability (either stunned or hibernating myocardium).

 
  • Viable myocardium can be revealed by raising blood levels of thallium by reinjection of a small dose (1 to 2 mCi) of thallium at rest. Thus, in some patients, thallium reinjection is necessary to identify viable myocardium when there are irreversible defects on stress-redistribution images.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 195, 196, 262.

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
• Urine analysis of a patient with hematuria and hypercalciuria is most likely to reveal isomorphic RBCs.
  • Hypercalciuria is a cause of non-glomerular hematuria.
  • RBCs from a non-glomerular source more closely resemble peripheral blood on microscopy, with isomorphic RBCs and absence of casts.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2280, 2304.

questions.text: What is the least likely scenario in which peripheral eosinophilia and renal failure could occur?
questions.solution:
Peripheral eosinophilia with renal failure is least likely in Polyarteritis nodosa.


Causes of Eosinophiluria: (>1% of urinary Leukocytes as Eosinophils)-
 
  1. Acute interstitial nephritis
  2. Acute rejection of renal allograft
  3. Acute glomerulonephritis (RPGN, PSGN)
  4. Chronic pyelonephritis
  5. Cholesterol embolization of kidney (atheroembolic renal failure)
  6. Bladder cancer
  7. Obstructive uropathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2281, 2304.

questions.text: On a CT scan, a lesion around the foramen of Monroe and several periventricular calcific foci are visible in the youngster who has elevated ICT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most probable diagnosis in a child with raised ICT, lesion around foramen of Monroe and multiple periventricular calcific foci on CT scan is subependymal giant cell astrocytoma.
  • It occurs in older children and young adults (<20 years) in the lateral wall of lateral ventricle overlying head of caudate nucleus near foramen of Monroe.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: Resection of which of the following segment would result in vitamin B12 absorption defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ileum
 
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the distal part of the small intestine, specifically the terminal ileum.
  • Resection or removal of the terminal ileum, such as in cases of Crohn's disease or surgical resection, can lead to impaired absorption of vitamin B12.
  • This can result in vitamin B12 deficiency and subsequent manifestations, such as megaloblastic anemia and neurological complications.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1316.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels has the lowest risk of suffering a serious injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option Is 3. Inferior mesenteric artery
 
  • Injury to inferior mesenteric artery is least likely to result in significant damage among the given options.
  • Occlusion of the inferior mesenteric artery does not always result in irreversible ischemia of the descending and sigmoid colon, because the marginal artery of the colon usually receives an adequate supply from the left branch of the middle colic artery.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1375.

choices.text: Isolate the proximal renal vessels, open the Gerota's fascia and explore the kidney

questions.text: One-shot IVU shows a barely discernible nephrogram on the right side and prompt uptake and excretion on the left side. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
CT provides Valuable information about the vascular pedicle (rule out renal artery stenosis/ renal vein thrombosis), the renal collecting systems, the perinephric space, and the retroperitoneal space.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1606.

choices.text: Ankle brachial index < 0.4 indicates critical limb ischemia
Ankle brachial index is different at rest than that during exercise
L-arginine is useful for providing endothelium-dependent vasorelaxation
Smoking has a greater association with peripheral vascular disease than coronary vascular disease

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Smoking has greater association with coronary artery disease than peripheral vascular disease.
L-Arginine is a precursor of Nitric oxide so helps in vasodilation due to synthesis of NO by endothelium. Hence it is endothelium-dependent.
Ankle brachial index <0.5 indicates critical limb ischemia.
ABI changes during exercise and rest.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1003.

choices.text: Laparoscopic exploration of CBD and removal of stone
Laparoscopic CBD extraction through the cystic duct

questions.text: While performing a laparoscopic surgery, a surgeon with little experience in laparoscopic cholecystectomy discovered some stones in the common bile duct. What should he do, ideally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Open CBD exploration
 
  • The surgeon should consider his or her limitations and be able to determine when degree of difficulty or uncertainty necessitates conversion of laparoscopic to open cholecystectomy.
  • Lap CBD exploration is an advanced surgery and if surgeon is not trained for this then he should convert the case and do open cholecystectomy and open CBD exploration.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1251.

questions.text: What is the most common postoperative complication of ileoanal pouch anastomosis in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 1. Pouchitis

Most common post-operative complication of ileoanal pouch anastomosis in ulcerative colitis is pouchitis.
Inflammation of the mucosa of the ileal pouch, or pouchitis, occurs in 7-33% of patients with UC treated by IPAA.( ileal pouch-anal anastomosis).
The cause is unknown but may be related to bacterial overgrowth, mucosa, ischemia, or other local factors.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1324.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a liver capsular plate?
questions.solution:
Portal plate is not a liver capsular plate. The fascial plates of the liver hilus, represents a fusion of endoabdominal fascia around the portal structures. The fascial plate is formed by: cystic, hilar and umbilical plate.




Reference-: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/liver

questions.text: Which of the following does not correlate with the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Level of amylase does not correlate with severity of acute pancreatitis.
Severe pancreatitis is diagnosed if three or more of the Ranson's criteria are fulfilled.
All the other factors in the options are included in the criteria which are checked either at the time or 48 hours after admission.



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1445.

questions.text: Where does cholangiocarcinoma typically occur?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Hilum

Most common site of cholangiocarcinoma is hilum.
  • They are divided into 3 types based  on pathogenesis-
    Sclerosing, Nodular, Papillary.
  • Clinical Features-
    Painless jaundice is MC symptom of cholangiocarcinoma, followed by pruritus, abdominal pain, weight loss ,fever.
  • Cholangio carcinomas are tumors arising from bile duct epithelium, most commonly adenocarcinomas.
  • MC gene mutation: K-ras >p16.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1216.

questions.text: Which of the following fruit juices can help prevent UTI if consumed on a regular basis?
questions.solution:
Regular drinking of cranberry juice can prevent UTI.
 
  • Cranberry juice is traditionally used for prophylaxis and treatment of UTI.
  • Cranberry juice contains proanthocyanidins that block adherence of pathogens to uroepithelial cells in vitro.
  • Non-antimicrobial prevention is increasingly being studied. Lactobacillus probiotics are one appealing approach to UTI prevention, but there is a paucity of data to support this strategy. Similarly, studies of cranberry products for UTI prevention have produced mixed results.


Reference: Jepson, R G et al. “Cranberries for treating urinary tract infections.” The Cochrane database of systematic reviews vol. 1998,2 (2000): CD001322. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD001322. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7025796/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ultrasound feature of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. High gastric residue

Ultrasonography is the investigation of choice to confirm diagnose of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis with accuracy> 95% (approaching almost 100%).
USG visualizes thickened and elongated pyloric canal.
USG criteria for diagnosis include >16 mm pyloric length and > 4 mm pyloric muscle wall thickness. Gastric residues are low because of recurrent emesis.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text: What is the preferred investigation for the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Barium swallow

Investigation of choice for diagnosis of Zenker’s diverticulum is barium swallow.
It is a mucosal outpouching (pulsion diverticulum) occurring through the triangular bare area (Kilian's triangle) between the upper oblique fibers (thyropharyngeus muscle) and lower horizontal fibers (cricopharyngeus muscle) of the inferior constrictor muscle.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1126.

questions.text: A femoral hernia is discovered in a patient. Which of the following structures is directly lateral to the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
• Femoral vein lies immediately lateral to the sac of hernia.

  • The lateral compartment is inhabited by the femoral artery, which is separated from the femoral ring by the femoral vein in an intermediate compartment.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with primary amenorrhea, normal sexual development and normal breasts, but absent pubic axillary hair. The examination shows bilateral inguinal hernias. Ultrasound shows an absent uterus and a blind vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Androgen Insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is when a person who is genetically male (who has one X and one Y chromosome) is resistant to male hormones (called androgens).
  • As a result, the person has some of the physical traits of a woman, but the genetic makeup of a man.
Clinical features of AIS:
  • Genetically male (46,XY) with female external genitalia
  • Absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina
  • Internal testes (often undescended)
  • Sparse or absent pubic and axillary hair
  • Normal breast development
  • Primary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation)
  • Infertility
  • Female gender identity
  • Increased risk of gonadal tumors if testes are not removed
  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome is treated with estrogen replacement therapy after puberty.
  • Undescended testicles will be surgically removed because of the risk that they will become cancerous.
  • Treatment for partial androgen insensitivity syndrome may include corrective surgery to match gender identity.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 113, 114.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal functioning of the ovaries seen?
questions.solution:
MRKH syndrome

A simple algorithm to differentiate different causes of primary amenorrhea .
    
Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: The aftercoming head of the baby in a breech delivery can be arrested by all of the following except:

.

  • In cases with cephalopelvic disproportion and arrest of aftercoming head, the Zavanelli maneuver or symphysiotomy are options.

questions.text: HRT is given to all postmenopausal women except:
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy can be useful in controlling menopausal symptoms (hot flushes, urogenital atrophy  etc.) and helping to prevent osteoporosis. 

It has also been suggested that although estrogen might reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, primarily by improving lipid profile or by vascular effects, estrogen may increase the injury resulting from ischemia, either by increased cell death pathways or by adverse remodeling.

Indications of HRT in Post-menopausal women:

  1. Relief of Vasomotor Symptoms:

    • Hot flashes and night sweats (moderate to severe).

  2. Management of Urogenital Symptoms:

    • Vaginal dryness, atrophic vaginitis, and urinary symptoms (local or systemic HRT).

  3. Prevention of Osteoporosis:

    • For women at high risk of fractures who cannot use other treatments.

  4. Premature or Early Menopause:

    • Women with menopause before age 40 or early menopause (ages 40-45).

  5. Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease:

    • For women under 60 or within 10 years of menopause (not recommended solely for cardiovascular protection).

  6. Mood and Sleep Disturbances:

    • Mood swings, anxiety, depression, and sleep disorders related to menopause.

  7. Quality of Life Improvement:

    • When menopausal symptoms significantly affect daily living.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-94.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the HPE given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malignant teratoma
 
  • Malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary composed of cells from the three germ layers, containing variable amounts of mature and immature tissue
  • Affects mostly young females < 20 years old
  • Grossly solid ovarian tumor mass with necrosis and hemorrhage on cut sections
  • Grading is performed based on the amount of immature neuroepithelium
  • Can have associated nodal or peritoneal gliomatosis (presence of mature neural tissue), which increases risk of recurrence
  • Grading and stage are the most important factors for prognosis, greatly improved after chemotherapy
Histopathological findings in Malignant Teratoma:
 
  • Immature Tissue Elements: Presence of primitive neuroectodermal tissue (neuroblasts, rosettes) and immature mesenchymal or epithelial tissue.
  • Malignant Components: Somatic malignancies such as squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcomas within the teratoma.
  • High-Grade Features: Cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and Hemorrhage: Common in malignant areas, reflecting the aggressive nature of the tumor.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 461.

questions.text: What is the important fatty acid that is present in breast milk and is important for the baby's growth?
questions.solution:
• The important fatty acid present in breast milk, which is important for baby growth is Docosahexanoic acid.
  • Up to 5-10% of fatty acids in human milk are poly-unsaturated. Most of these are Linoleic acid with smaller amounts of Linolenic acid. Linoleic acid gives rise to arachidonic acid.
  • Linolenic acid gives rise to Docosahexanoic acid. Docosahexanoic acid is found in human milk and brain lipids and is required for the development of othe nervous system and visual abilities during the first six months of life.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 307

questions.text: What is the disease for which the NESTROFT test is used in screening?
questions.solution:
• NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is used in screening of Beta-thalassemia.
  • The principle of NESTROFT is based on the limit of hypotonicity, which the red cell can withstand.
  • Positive test is due to the reduced osmotic fragility of red cells.
  • NESTROFT is also positive in other conditions, which are associated with decreased red cell osmotic fragility such as Hereditary spherocytosis, liver disease and hemoglobinopathies.

Hereditary Spherocytosis:
 
  • Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition where red blood cells are sphere-shaped due to defects in membrane proteins.
  • Osmotic fragility testing is indeed used here because spherocytes are more prone to lysis in hypotonic solutions.
  • However, the standard osmotic fragility test (OFT) is performed, not NESTROFT.
  • NESTROFT is specifically tailored for detecting red cell resistance to lysis, characteristic of beta-thalassemia.




Reference: Piplani, Sanjay et al. “NESTROFT - A Valuable, Cost Effective Screening Test for Beta Thalassemia Trait in North Indian Punjabi Population.” Journal of clinical and diagnostic research : JCDR vol. 7,12 (2013): 2784-687. doi:10.7860/JCDR/2013/6834.3759. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3919310/

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis. An X-ray of the chest reveals dextrocardia and situs inversus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a child with history of recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis with dextrocardia and situs inversus on chest X-ray is Kartagener 's syndrome.
  • It is also known as Primary ciliary dyskinesia.
  • It occurs due to mutation in dynein protein of cilia. 
  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) comprises those respiratory disorders having in common the malfunction of airway cilia.
  • About 50% of patients with PCD have Kartagener's syndrome: Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, otitis and airway disease leading to bronchiectasis.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2298,2299

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who was evaluated for her short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was decreased, and her TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
With long standing hypothyroidism, thyrotroph hyperplasia can result in expansion of sella turcica and the enlargement of the pituitary gland. This may mimic pituitary tumour.
In long standing hypothyroidism, the negative feedback of thyroid hormones on hypothalamus is lost. This results in increase secretion of thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. This in turn causes hyperplasia and proliferation of the thyrotrophic cells of the pituitary.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2935.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is not found in Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Deletion of chromosome number 21 is not seen in Down's syndrome.
  • Most of Down's syndromes have trisomy 21, so their chromosome count is 47.
  • In some cases of Down syndrome, the extra chromosomal material derives from the presence of a robertsonian translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentric chromosome (e.g., 22 or 14).
  • Approximately 1% of Down syndrome patients are mosaics. usually having a mixture of cells with 46 and 47 chromosomes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 635

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child has had episodic anemia and jaundice since birth. Which one of the following is he least likely to have?

  • Jaundice at the time of birth makes the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia the least likely among the given options.

questions.text: A newborn displays all of the following thermogenic mechanisms when exposed to cold, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• Neonates lack shivering mechanism.
  • Due to their high surface area-to-volume ratio, infants tend to lose more heat to the environment as compared to adults.
  • In addition, human newborns lack sufficiently developed skeletal muscle mass to maintain body temperature through shivering thermogenesis, an important source of heat in cold-exposed adults.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 872

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with non-blanching macules and papules on the skin. A skin biopsy revealed a perivascular IgA deposition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of non-blanching palpable purpura (vasculitis of skin) and colicky abdominal pain (vasculitis of gastrointestinal tract) in a five-year-old child together with evidence of lgA deposition in immune complexes suggests the diagnosis of Henoch Scholein Purpura. HSP is a systemic vasculitis syndrome involving small and medium size vessels.

Pathogenesis and clinical feature: 
  • The presumptive pathogenic mechanism for IgA (Henoch-Schönlein) vasculitis is immune-complex deposition.
  • In pediatric patients, palpable purpura is seen in virtually all patients; most patients develop polyarthralgias in the absence of frank arthritis. Gastrointestinal involvement, which is seen in almost 70% of pediatric patients

Diagnosis: 
  • The diagnosis of IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein) is based on clinical signs and symptoms.
  • Skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.
  • Renal biopsy is rarely needed for diagnosis but may provide prognostic information in some patients.

DIF of skin 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2814.

questions.text: Which medication is best for treating congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by a 21-alpha hydroxylase deficiency during pregnancy itself?
questions.solution:

choices.text: Anaerobic metabolism in the fetus can cause acidemia
Low APGAR score at 1 minute indicates the need for immediate PPV
Low APGAR score at 7 minutes indicates neonatal death/mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding oxygenation of the fetus or neonate is not true?
questions.solution:
Option (4) statement is not true.
APGAR score at 7-10 minutes, if low, may indicate cerebral palsy/morbidity but not death/mortality (option 4).
According to NRP, neonatal resuscitation is continued for 20 minutes and if there is no heart rate/breathing at 20 minutes - only then is neonatal resuscitation stopped and child is declared to have died. 

Other options

  • Option 1 - True: Anaerobic metabolism due to inadequate oxygenation leads to lactic acid buildup and acidemia, which is a known fetal response to hypoxia.

  • Option 2 -True: The foetus relies on the placenta for gas exchange, and CO is washed out via placental circulation to the mother’s lungs for excretion.

  • Option 3 - True: If the child is gasping or apneic/bradycardic (HR<100) at 1 minute after initial steps of resuscitation which in turn would lead to low APGAR- child requires positive pressure ventilation and immediate resuscitation. 




Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 872

•Pachygyria

•Heterotopia

questions.text: On examination, there is weakness in the extension of the right great toe with no sensory impairment. An MRI of the lumbosacral spine will most likely reveal a prolapsed intervertebral disc at what level?

choices.text: What should be the loading dose of IV methylprednisolone

questions.text:
A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of falling from a tree within 2 hours of the injury. On examination, he is unable to move both his lower limbs and has absent sensations at the umbilicus and bladder-bowel involvement. Spinal tenderness is elicited at the level of D10-L2. What should be the loading dose of IV methylprednisolone
for treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 30 mg/kg within 3 hours
 
  • The clinical presentation suggests a spinal cord injury with neurological deficit (SCIWORA) due to trauma.
  • Although there is not enough evidence supporting routine use of high-dose intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone in SCIWORA patients, some studies suggest potential efficacy after SCI if it is started within the first eight hours of trauma with additional benefit by extending the maintenance dose from 24 to 48 hours
  • Hence, IV methylprednisolone bolus of 30 mg/kg within eight hours of injury, followed by infusion at 5.4 mg/kg/hr for the next 48 hours can be beneficial in improving outcomes.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1839.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with CV junction anomalies?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ankylosing spondylitis is least likely associated with CV junction anomaly. Classification of Craniovertebral Junction Abnormalities-
1) Congenital malformations-
•Malformations of the occipital sclerotomes( Basilar invagination)
•Malformation of the atlas
•Malformations of the axis
 
2) Developmental and acquired abnormalities-
•Foramen magnum abnormalities
•Atlanto axial instability. ( Rheumatoid arthritis)
•Traumatic atlanto-axlal dislocation



Reference- https://radiopaedia.org/articles/craniovertebral-junction-anomalies

questions.text: Topical administration of 1% pilocarpine failed to produce pupillary constriction in a patient who had a large, dilated pupil. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Pharmacological blockade

Anisocoria which increases in light is differentiated on the basis of “Ocular mobility” and “Pilocarpine test”.
 
  • On application of Pilocarpine 0.125%, pupils constrict in Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil. In cases of Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil/ fixed dilated pupil, constriction is seen with Pilocarpine 0.1%. 
  • In case of no constriction, Pilocarpine 1% is added: Constriction implies 3rd nerve palsy whereas No constriction implies Pharmacological mydriasis. 

1% Pilocarpine is a sufficient miotic dose for any eye, but a sphincter with all its cholinergic receptor blockade by atropine or tropicamide (i.e. eye with pharmacological blockade) does not constrict with pilocarpine 1%.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 965, 966.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is currently used for the prophylaxis of non-infectious uveitis in the LUMINATE program?
questions.solution:
In LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) programme a pivotal study LUVENIQ (LX-211) assessed the safety and efficacy of oral form of next generation calcineurin inhibitor, Voclosporin for treatment of sight threatening non-infectious uveitis (as a steroid sparing therapy).



Reference: Anglade, Eddy et al. “A new agent for the treatment of noninfectious uveitis: rationale and design of three LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) trials of steroid-sparing voclosporin.” Clinical ophthalmology (Auckland, N.Z.) vol. 2,4 (2008): 693-702. doi:10.2147/opth.s2452

questions.text: The Mizuo phenomenon is seen during:
questions.solution:
Mizuo-Nakumara phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease.
  • Oguchi's disease is an autosomal recessive form of congenital stationary night blindness and is caused by a disruption in the steps of inactivation of rod phototransduction.
  • The Mizuo phenomenon is a term used to describe reversible changes in the fundus color from a gold leaf-like reflex under light conditions to the normal orange–red color after full dark adaptation, which is typically seen in Oguchi's disease.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 488.

questions.text: A young adult appears with proptosis and pain in the right eye two days after an eye trauma. On examination, he has a bruise on his right eye and forehead. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a young adult with history of trauma to the eye with proptosis and pain in the right eye and bruise on the right eye and forehead is Carotico-cavernous fistula.
A carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is the result of an abnormal vascular connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) or external carotid artery (ECA) and the venous channels of the cavernous sinus.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1814.

questions.text: Four days after an eye trauma, a patient comes with proptosis and ocular pain. He displays chemosis, conjunctival congestion, and extraocular muscular palsies on examination. What is the preferred investigation to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a post-traumatic carotico-cavernous fistula includes symptoms of proptosis and pain in the eye after an eye trauma with chemosis, conjunctival congestion, and extraocular muscle palsies on examination.
Intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography is the preferred test to make a diagnosis.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1814.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about oculomotor nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Miosis. Complete Oculomotor Palsy leads to Mydriasis, NOT Miosis.
 
  • Along with the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and pupillary sphincter, the oculomotor nerve innervates four extraocular muscles: the medial, superior & inferior rectus and inferior oblique. As a result, during palsy there is total ptosis (Option 2)
  • Nerve to IO carries along with it nerve fibres supplying Sphinter pupillae via Short ciliary nerves; so there is dilated pupil when the palsy is complete (mydriasis, not the miosis). This is due to Sphincter denervation.
  • The affected eye is also turned outward (laterally), typically downward (Option 3).
  • Thus, it also leads to impaired visual fixation resulting in Diplopia (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: What proportion of endothelial cells are lost during the automated penetrating keratoplasty of Descemet's membrane stripping?
questions.solution:
Percentage of endothelial cell loss during Descemet 's membrane stripping in automated penetrating keratoplasty 30-40% .
  • Following DSEK/DSAEK the endothelial cell loss rate can be as high as 56% in the first year, although with standardized technique, the endothelial cell loss has been reduced to less than 35%.
  • The incidence of endothelial cell loss in donor tissue of Descemet stripping endothelial keratoplasty is nearly 35%, mainly in the central area of graft. Compared with penetrating keratoplasty, EK involves more donor-tissue manipulation including lamellar dissection and folding, which could potentially damage donor endothelium.
  • Therefore, best possible answer should be Option 3> Option 4.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 389.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with a sudden and severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, with no perception of light. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflexes, fundus examination, and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could close her right eye and touch the tips of her fingers, but not her left. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this young lady who presents with sudden severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, with no perception of light and normal examination findings including pupillary reflexes, fundus and optokinetic nystagmus, who is able to touch tips of her finger with right eye closed but not with left eye closed, is functional vision loss.

Other options:
  • Option 1: Optic neuritis- ON presents with sudden painful DOV, and the pain increases on eye movements. Also ON shows abnormal light reflex like RAPD. Fundus is abnormal except Retrobulbar neuritis.
  • Option 2: AION- AION generally presents with altitudinal hemianopia. It also shows positive RAPD. Fundus shows Optic disc changes.
  • Option 3: CMV retinitis typically occurs in HIV affected patients with CD4 cell count < 50/microlitre. Fundus examination shows Cotton wool spots, Pizza pie appearance and Brushfire appearance.
Evaluating for an rAPD is very useful in the setting of functional vision loss because it is purely objective. Here the patient has normal pupillary light reflex and no significant changes in other objective tests also. Therefore, Functional vision loss is the most appropriate answer (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 704, 887, 892, 964.

questions.text: Which are the most radioresistant cells in the retina?
questions.solution:
#Controversial
1>2

The most radioresistant cells in the retina are the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). (answer confirmed by Ophthalmology faculty at AIIMS, Delhi)

RPE cells are relatively resistant to radiation due to their low mitotic activity and high metabolic capacity. In contrast, other retinal cells, such as ganglion cells, rods and cones, and bipolar cells, are more sensitive due to their higher turnover rates and metabolic demands.

Thus, the correct answer is: Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Reference: Early Ultrastructural Changes After Low-dose X-irradiation in the Retina of the Rat, Nature (1989), URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/eye198998.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Herpes Zoster keratitis?
questions.solution:
Herpes Zoster ophthalmicus commonly causes acute epithelial keratitis [i.e. punctuate epithelial keratitis and pseudo dendritic keratitis, anterior stromal keratitis, disciform (deep stromal) keratitis or endothelitis and serpiginous ulceration. However, sclero-keratitis (limbal vascular keratitis) is least common.

Other options:
Option 1: Active viral infections tend to affect the epithelium, leading to punctate epithelial keratitis and pseudo-dendrites
Option 2: It is characterized by multiple, fine, granular, coin-shaped infiltrates in the anterior stroma and may cause permanent scarring
Option 4: Disciform keratitis is a deep stromal infiltrate that develops 3–4 months after the acute phase, characterized by a central disc-shaped area of diffuse corneal edema that results from endotheliitis and anterior chamber inflammation


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 180.

questions.text: Which of the following is a FDA approved intravitreal steroid therapy for the treatment of Diabetic macular edema?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 0.7% Dexamethasone
 
  • Ozurdex is a dexamethasone implant in a concentration of 0.7mg which is used for the treatment of macular edema due to central retinal vein occlusion.
  • The dexamethasone intravitreal implant containing 700 μg dexamethasone (Ozurdex, Allergan, Irvine, CA) in a solid polymer drug delivery system that is also approved by the FDA for treatment of diabetic macular edema, in addition to macular edema from vein occlusions and uveitis.
  • The MEAD study showed that 0.7 mg dexamethasone resulted in 22% treated eyes versus 12% sham eyes gaining 15 or more letters.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 550.

questions.text:
Eczematous dermatitis covering the extensor surfaces is seen in a 3-year-old child.
Bronchial asthma had already affected his mother.
What should be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most probable diagnosis in a 3-year old child, who presents with eczematous dermatitis over the extensor surfaces with family history of bronchial asthma is atopic dermatitis.
  • AD is a cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, hay fever or dermatitis.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.16

questions.text: In which case is intra-epidermal intercellular deposition of IgG on immunofluorescence most common?
questions.solution:
Intra-epidermal intercellular deposition of IgG on immunofluorescence is seen in Pemphigus.
  • It is an autoimmune disease characterized by acantholysis induced by the deposition of lgG antibodies in the intercellular area of the epidermis.
  • The commonest variant of pemphigus is Pemphigus vulgaris, seen in adults mainly.
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis is a rare neutrophilic dermatosis with sterile pustules in subcorneal level. 




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: In which case is granular deposition of IgA at dermal papillae on immunofluorescence most common?
questions.solution:
• Granular deposition of lgA at dermal papillae on immunofluorescence is seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • It is associated with subclinical gluten sensitive enteropathy.
  • Itchy blisters appear in fingers, elbows and knees. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct immunofluorescence microscopy of normal appearing or faintly erythematous perilesional skin (adjacent to active lesion), by demonstration of granular deposits of lgA (with or without complements) in papillary dermis and along the epidermal basement membrane zone.
Below is an image of characteristic lesion seen in DH and its IF.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.52, 50.53

questions.text: Which is the only indication of systemic corticosteroids in psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• One of the indications of systemic corticosteroids in psoriasis is impetigo herpetiformis. Pustular psoriasis in pregnancy is called impetigo herpetiformis.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare but severe form of psoriasis that typically occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by pustules, erythema, and scaling.
  • Safest drug for treatment of Impetigo herpetiformis is prednisolone as it doesn't cause teratogenicity or any harm to fetus. 
  • Below is an image of impetigo herpetiformis



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.37

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is included in the syndromic management of genital ulcer syndrome in India?
questions.solution:
The syndromic management of genital ulcer syndrome in India includes chancroid, primary chancre and herpes simplex.




Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK572660/

questions.text: A man with a 6-month history of recurrent oral ulceration has a yellowish ulceration on his lip that is erythematous with a central halo and nodular lesions on his shin. What ailment does he most likely have?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of a patient who presents with a 6-month history of recurrent oral ulceration, yellowish ulcerations on the lip, erythematous , with a central halo and nodular lesions on shin is Behcet's disease.
  • It is chronic multisystem relapsing vascular inflammatory disease (vasculitis) of unknown origin.
 
  • The most common symptoms are associated with mucocutaneous tissues. Oral ulcers are seen in virtually all patients and are commonly the first manifestation. Commonly, like ordinary cancer sores, they are usually multiple. They last around 10 days but recur unless treated. Only the uncommon, major ulcers tend to scar.
 
  • Genital ulcers are the most specific lesions, most commonly occurring on the scrotum or labia. They are larger and deeper and take longer to heal than oral ulcers and tend to form scars.

Behcet's disease has a clinical triad of:
  1. Oral ulcers
  2. Genital ulcers
  3. Arthritis


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2817, 2818.

questions.text: What causes EEG slowing during anaesthesia induction?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hypothermia
 
  • EEG slowing/suppression during induction of anesthesia is due to Hypothermia.
  • Profound hypothermia leads to completely electrically silent EEG. 
  •  During anesthesia induction, the brain's activity slows down, which is reflected in the EEG as a decrease in frequency and amplitude. This slowing of EEG activity is a normal response to anesthesia and is caused by the action of anesthetics on the brain.
  • Hypothermia, or a decrease in body temperature, is a common side effect of anesthesia. It can occur due to a number of factors, including exposure to cold operating room temperatures, administration of cold intravenous fluids, and decreased metabolic rate.
  • Hypothermia can lead to a decrease in brain activity, which is reflected in the EEG as slowing of the frequency and amplitude.
  • Ketamine and nitrous oxide are also commonly used anesthetics, but they do not typically cause EEG slowing during induction. Early hypoxia, or a decrease in oxygen supply to the brain, can cause EEG changes, but it is not a common cause of EEG slowing during anesthesia induction.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1275.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Xenon in anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Slow induction and slow recovery
 
  • Xenon  is inert, non-explosive, environment friendly having low blood solubility with minimal cardiovascular side effects.
  • Xenon is one of the most ideal anesthetic agent but as it's rare element it's not used much for anesthesia. 
  • Xenon has favorable pharmacodynamic effects in comparison to most inhaled anesthetics. It produces minimal cardiovascular depression and is not arrhythmogenic.
  • Lower blood gas coefficient of Xenon results in rapid induction and recovery.
  • Its solubility in blood (λb/g = 0.14) and body tissues is lower than that of any other inhaled anesthetic, including N2O. As a result, it has extraordinarily rapid onset and respiratory clearance, with emergence times 2 to 3-fold faster when it replaces N2O in clinical settings.
  • It is seldom used in clinical practice because of high cost.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 537, 566-568.

questions.text: Which of the following Best determines an arachnoid cyst from an epidermoid cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Restricted diffusion. 
Shown by epidermoid and not dermoid cyst.
 
  • On MRI, epidermoid cysts have signal intensity close to that of CSF on T1, T2 and FLAIR images, which can make them difficult to distinguish from other cystic lesions such as arachnoid cysts.
  • The latter often have better defined margins and cause bone thinning. DWI is the most helpful MRI sequence for making the diagnosis of epidermoid tumours. They appear bright on DWI, as opposed to arachnoid cysts, which appear dark, like CSF.






Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1432.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for leptomeningeal carcinomatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Gadolinium enhancement MRI.

Leptomeningeal metastases/carcinomatous meningitis/meningeal carcinomatosis:
 
  • Spread of malignant cells through CSF space. 
  • The malignant cells can originate from primary CNS tumors in the form of drop metastases and from distant tumors that have metastasized via hematogenous spread.
  • Gadolinium enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis which shows leptomeningeal enhancement along gyri and sulci. 
  • Contrast-enhanced MRI is much more sensitive than contrast-enhanced CT for detection of metastatic meningeal involvement. Carcinomatosis of the dura mater, common in carcinoma of the breast, manifests itself as focal curvilinear or diffuse contrast enhancement closely applied to the inner table of the skull, which does not follow the convolutions of the gyri.
  • Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis produces linear or finely nodular contrast enhancement of the surface of the brain, extending into the sulci and following the convolutions of the brain.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1432.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with gradually worsening lower-limb weakness, spasticity, and recent onset micturition hesitancy. On neurological examination, there is evidence of dorsal myelopathy. An MRI scan of the spine reveals a middorsal intradural contrast-enhancing mass lesion. What ailment does she most likely have?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in a middle aged female with slowly progressive weakness of lower limbs, spasticity and recent onset hesitancy of micturition with evidence of dorsal myelopathy and mid-dorsal intradural contrast enhancing mass lesion on MRI is meningioma.
  • They are derived from meningomesothelial cells of arachnoid.
  • It mostly occur along the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Most are slow growing and encapsulated.
  • Meningiomas are often located posterior to the thoracic cord or near the foramen magnum, although they can arise from the meninges anywhere along the spinal canal.

MRI of spinal Meningioma



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3448.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1430, 1431.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with intracranial cavernous angioma on an MRI scan. What are the characteristics of the lesion's MRI findings?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Reticulates pop-corn like calcification.

Cerebral cavernous venous malformations/cavernous hemangiomas/cavernomas: 
  • Mulberry like lesions consisting of multiple vascular spaces with little intervening brain parenchyma. 
  • It is a type of arteriovenous malformation which in most of the cases is an incidentally detected finding. Can sometimes present with epilepsy. 
  • CT- Characterized by a relatively well-defined, dense or calcified lesion with patchy contrast enhancement. 
  • MRI is the modality of choice. Gradient-echo susceptibility sequence is very sensitive to diagnose a cavernoma. 
  • Popcorn appearance- Described on MRI. Refers to central mixed signal intensity due to blood products of varying ages surrounded by a dark hemosiderin rim. 
  • Cavernous malformations can be grouped into four types based on MRI appearances using the Zabramski classification.




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1476.

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful for spondylolisthesis diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: X-Ray lumbar spine AP view.

X-Ray lumbar spine in AP view cannot demonstrate sliding of one vertebra over other which is seen in spondylolisthesis. Therefore, among the given options, it will be least useful as an imaging modality for the condition. 
 
  • A spondylolisthesis, also known as an anterolisthesis, is an anterior displacement of a vertebral body relative to the vertebra below.
  • On imaging, a lateral conventional radiograph shows anterolisthesis with degenerative changes at the facet joint and disc space narrowing.
  • CT and MRI will show osteoarthritis of the facet joints and associated spondylolisthesis. The sagittal orientation of the facet joints, as well as disc degeneration and/or disc bulging, can be evaluated. MRI can also determine the nerve compression if present. 



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1262.

questions.text: What feature does somatic passivity possess?
questions.solution:
• Schneider's first rank symptoms of Schizophrenia are:
  1. Hallucinations,
  2. Delusional perception,
  3. Thought alienations and
  4. Passivity phenomenon (Somatic passivity).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 328.
Magrangeas, Thibault Thierry et al. “Investigating the relationship between thought interference, somatic passivity and outcomes in patients with psychosis: a natural language processing approach using a clinical records search platform in south London.” BMJ open vol. 12,8 e057433. 2 Aug. 2022, doi:10.1136/bmjopen-2021-057433

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not related to panic attacks?
questions.solution:
• Biological etiology of panic disorder is related to abnormalities in the function of a variety of neurotransmitters including serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT), noradrenaline (norepinephrine), gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), dopamine, and cholecystokinin.
  • Glutamate is not involved in the pathology.
  • Low levels of GABA have been associated with anxiety disorders, including panic attacks.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a neuropeptide that is involved in the regulation of appetite, anxiety, and pain. It is found in high concentrations in the amygdala, which is a brain region that is involved in fear and anxiety

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 389, 393.

choices.text: Transfer of psychic energy from the body parts to the brain

questions.text: What is counter-transference?
questions.solution:
• Counter transference occurs when a physician irrationally transfers to a patient his feelings and attitudes derived from past (childhood) experiences.
  • It is suspected whenever physician has powerful feelings of affection, protectiveness, frustration, fear, irritation, hatred or erotic excitement towards a patient; when they very much look forward to the next appointment; or when they cannot tolerate a particular patient.
  • Transference is the feeling of patient towards therapist. 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 866, 867.

questions.text: Which of the following was recently discovered as a risk factor associated with a Type D personality?
questions.solution:
• Type D personality is a personality trait characterized by negative emotions, social inhibition, and the tendency to experience stress.
  • Type D personality has been recently found to be a risk factor for coronary artery disease.
  • Type D (distressed) personality is not only a risk factor for the development of ischemic heart disease, it also leads to a worse prognosis following a myocardial infarction. 



Reference: Personality as independent predictor of long-term mortality in patients with coronary heart disease, Denollet, J et al.
The Lancet, Volume 347, Issue 8999, 417 - 421. doi: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(96)90007-0/

questions.text: Which combination is present in type II bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hypomania + depression

Bipolar disorder or manic depressive psychosis is characterized by unpredictable swings in mood from mania (or hypomania) to depression at different times and in the intervening period, the patient may be normal.

Type I bipolar disorder 
Characterized by a clinical course of 2:1 manic (severe) episodes (which last for at least one week) and sometimes major (severe) depressive episodes (however may not be present and not necessary for diagnosis)

Type II bipolar disorder 
Combination of Hypomania (a milder form of mania lasting for 4 days) and depressive episodes (necessary for diagnosis).


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 356, 364.
